narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: Thinking about real world situations from new perspectives, incentive compatibility, analyzing best responses in market scenarios, and more applications of game theory to different areas of society.

I loved this class. I love Econ 159, and I wanted more of the same. This class delivered. I wish it was longer, and I wish we covered more. I developed skills in considering conditional probability, assignment problems, more in-depth understanding of repeated interactions, and efficiency-equity tradeoffs.
I was able to continue to learn about the interesting logic and probability surrounding game theory and the real life applications of these concepts.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: Strengths - great teachers, interesting content for the most part. Weaknesses - lectures could be a bit more interactive given that it is a game theory course.

Strengths: Ben Polak is an elite teacher. The material is super interesting. It's super cool to take a class in the SOM (I'm just a humble undergrad). We learn a lot, but it's not super difficult (if you didn't find ECON 159 so hard; I've been told I have a skewed perception of the difficulty). Clear lectures.

Weaknesses: Only six weeks. Meets during reading week. I refuse to accept the results of one lecture on conditional thinking and common knowledge. (THE MESSENGER GAME IS A LIE!!!) But overall, not a lot.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Yes. Fun and easy class. Topics covered are interesting and both profs are good.
I would certainly recommend introduction to game theory (Econ 159) to any student, but I would only take this course if you are very interested in the subject
Absolutely! If you liked ECON 159, you should definitely take! I loved it! It's just such an interesting way of thinking.
Yes, love Ben Polak and Joyee Deb
If you have already taken game theory then I would suggest this as a continuation class.
